PREFACE
   This code of the Village of Bloomingdale, as supplemented, contains
ordinances up to and including ordinance 2025-24, passed May 27, 2025.
Ordinances of the Village adopted after said ordinance supersede the provisions
of this code to the extent that they are in conflict or inconsistent therewith.
Consult the Village office in order to ascertain whether any particular
provision of the code has been amended, superseded or repealed.
American Legal Publishing
Cincinnati, Ohio

publisher, and they may not amend the code of ordinances. Additionally,
ordinances listed in this section may not show the original ordinances in their
entirety. Please contact the office of the clerk if there are any questions
concerning any listed ordinances.

ORDINANCE NO. 2025-34
 
AN ORDINANCE
AMENDING TITLE 7 (MOTOR VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC) OF THE VILLAGE CODE OF THE
VILLAGE OF BLOOMINGDALE, AS AMENDED;
(IMPOUNDMENT OF VEHICLES; ADMINISTRATIVE PENALTY)
 
   WHEREAS, the Village of Bloomingdale, DuPage County, Illinois (the
“Village”) is a home rule unit of local government under Article VII, Section 6
of the 1970 Illinois Constitution and, except as limited by such Section, it
may exercise any power and perform any function pertaining to its government
and affairs;
   WHEREAS, the Illinois Constitution of 1970 provides that a Home Rule Unit
may exercise any power and perform any function pertaining to its government
and affairs, including but not limited to the power to regulate for the
protection of the public health, safety, morals and welfare; to license, to
tax; and to incur debt;
   WHEREAS, the Village has in full force and effect a codified set of those
ordinances of the Village which are of a general and permanent nature, which
said codified set is known and designated as the Village Code of the Village of
Bloomingdale, as amended;
   WHEREAS, Title 7 of the Village Code governs the use of motor vehicles and
provides general traffic regulations and related penalty and fee schedules
within the Village;
   WHEREAS, the Village desires to modify certain fee schedules concerning the
impoundment of vehicles by amending Title 7 (Motor Vehicles and Traffic)
Chapter 7 (Impoundment of Vehicles) Section 7-7-3 (Administrative Penalty;
Vehicle Possession) of the Village Code;
   WHEREAS, the Corporate Authorities of the Village of Bloomingdale are of the
opinion that the foregoing actions are in the best interest of the public
safety, health and welfare of the residents of the Village of Bloomingdale.
   NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED by the Village President and Board of
Trustees of the Village of Bloomingdale, DuPage County, Illinois as follows:
Section One – Recitals
   The Corporate Authorities hereby find that all of the recitals hereinbefore
stated as contained in the preamble to the Ordinance are full, true and correct
and do hereby, by reference, incorporate and make them part of this Ordinance
as legislative findings.
Section Two – Amendment to Title 7 Chapter 7
   Title 7 (Motor Vehicles and Traffic) Chapter 7 (Impoundment of Vehicles)
Section 7-7-3 (Administrative Penalty; Vehicle Possession) shall be amended,
added language being reflected by underlined text and removed language
reflected by stricken text:
 
7-7-3: ADMINISTRATIVE PENALTY; VEHICLE POSSESSION:
A. A vehicle may be seized, towed and impounded by the village police
department without prior notice to the registered owner and lienholder thereof,
if applicable, when such vehicle or the operator thereof is believed to have
caused any of the following violations. The village shall not be liable for any
damage to any vehicle which occurs as a result of the towing and storage of any
vehicle under the provisions of this chapter. In addition to all applicable
towing and storage costs, an administrative penalty of seven-hundred and fifty
dollars ($750.00)five hundred dollars ($500.00) shall be imposed on the
registered owner (but not a vehicle lienholder or vehicle leasing company, in
which case, the lessee of the vehicle shall be responsible) of any such vehicle
towed or impounded as a consequence of the following violations. Such fee or
bond posted in lieu thereof shall be subject to refund or return, as the case
may be, in the event of a finding of no violation at a hearing conducted to
contest such violation as further prescribed in this chapter.
 
Section Three – Codification
The title, chapter(s) and section(s) adopted by this Ordinance shall be
numbered and placed in an appropriate title, chapter(s), and sections(s)
sections when and during the codification of the Bloomingdale Municipal Code.
Section Four – Effective Date:
This Ordinance shall be in full force and effect from and after its passage,
approval and publication as provided by law.
Section Five - Publication
This Ordinance shall be published in book or pamphlet form as provided by the
Illinois Municipal Code.
Section Six - Conflict Clause
That all ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict with the terms of this
Ordinance shall be repealed to the extent of said conflict.
Section Seven – Saving Clause
If any section, paragraph, clause or provision of this Ordinance is declared by
a court of law to be invalid or unconstitutional, the invalidity or
unconstitutionality thereof shall not affect the validity of the remaining
provisions of the Village’s Municipal Code, which are hereby declared to be
separable.
Section Eight - Recording
This Ordinance shall be entered into the minutes and upon the journals of the
Board of Trustees of the Village of Bloomingdale.

ORDINANCE NO. 2025-36
 
AN ORDINANCE
AMENDING TITLE 7 (MOTOR VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC); CHAPTER 3 (TRAFFIC SCHEDULES);
SECTION 2 (STOP INTERSECTIONS) OF THE VILLAGE CODE OF THE VILLAGE OF
BLOOMINGDALE, AS AMENDED, TO ESTABLISH AN ALL-WAY STOP CONTROL AT THE
INTERSECTION OF CIRCLE AVENUE AND SPRING VALLEY DRIVE
 
   WHEREAS, the Village of Bloomingdale, DuPage County, Illinois (the
“Village”) is a home rule unit of local government under Article VII, Section 6
of the 1970 Illinois Constitution and, except as limited by such Section, it
may exercise any power and perform any function pertaining to its government
and affairs;
   WHEREAS, the Illinois Constitution of 1970 provides that a Home Rule Unit
may exercise any power and perform any function pertaining to its government
and affairs, including but not limited to the power to regulate for the
protection of the public health, safety, morals and welfare; to license, to
tax; and to incur debt;
   WHEREAS, the Village has in full force and effect a codified set of those
ordinances of the Village which are of a general and permanent nature, which
said codified set is known and designated as the Village Code of the Village of
Bloomingdale, as amended;
   WHEREAS, pursuant to 625 ILCS 5/11-304, the Village Board may establish that
certain intersecting streets under the Village’s jurisdiction should be
controlled by the establishment of either two-way or all-way stop controls;
   WHEREAS, the Village Engineer has undertaken engineering traffic
investigation pursuant to the applicable standards published in the 2009
Edition of the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices (hereinafter the
“MUTCD”), and has presented his findings to the Village Board;
   WHEREAS, the Village Board desires to establish two-way stop control for
Hingham Lane at Braintree Drive to address safety concerns for, that the road
users to stop in compliance with the normal right-of-way rules; and
   WHEREAS, the Corporate Authorities of the Village of Bloomingdale are of the
opinion that the foregoing actions are in the best interest of the public
safety, health and welfare of the residents of the Village of Bloomingdale.
   NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED by the Village President and Board of
Trustees of the Village of Bloomingdale, DuPage County, Illinois as follows:
Section One – Recitals
   The Corporate Authorities hereby find that all of the recitals hereinbefore
stated as contained in the preamble to the Ordinance are full, true and correct
and do hereby, by reference, incorporate and make them part of this Ordinance
as legislative findings.
Section Two – Amendment to Title 7 Chapter 3
   Title 7 (Motor Vehicles and Traffic) Chapter 3 (Traffic Schedules) Section 2
(Stop Intersections) shall be repealed in its entirety and replaced with the
following:
 
7-3-2: STOP INTERSECTIONS:
 
The following street intersections are hereby designated as stop intersections
in the manner hereinafter provided, and all vehicular traffic shall stop before
entering or crossing the intersections so designated:
 
 
Street/Site  Direction of Traffic Location
Hingham Lane Eastbound            Hingham Lane at Braintree Drive
Hingham Lane Westbound            Hingham Lane at Braintree Drive
 
 
 
Section Three – Codification
The title, chapter(s) and section(s) adopted by this Ordinance shall be
numbered and placed in an appropriate title, chapter(s), and sections(s)
sections when and during the codification of the Bloomingdale Municipal Code.
 
Section Four – Effective Date:
This Ordinance shall be in full force and effect from and after its passage,
approval and publication as provided by law.
Section Five - Publication
This Ordinance shall be published in book or pamphlet form as provided by the
Illinois Municipal Code.
Section Six - Conflict Clause
That all ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict with the terms of this
Ordinance shall be repealed to the extent of said conflict.
Section Seven – Saving Clause
If any section, paragraph, clause or provision of this Ordinance is declared by
a court of law to be invalid or unconstitutional, the invalidity or
unconstitutionality thereof shall not affect the validity of the remaining
provisions of the Village’s Municipal Code, which are hereby declared to be
separable.
Section Eight - Recording
This Ordinance shall be entered into the minutes and upon the journals of the
Board of Trustees of the Village of Bloomingdale.

ADOPTING ORDINANCE
ORDINANCE NO. 2012-14
AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING THE VILLAGE OF BLOOMINGDALE MUNICIPAL CODE, EXCLUDING
TITLE 11 (ZONING REGULATIONS), AS AN EXERCISE OF THE HOME RULE AUTHORITY OF THE
VILLAGE OF BLOOMINGDALE, DUPAGE COUNTY, ILLINOIS
WHEREAS, the village of Bloomingdale, DuPage County, Illinois (the "village")
is a home rule unit of local government, and as such may exercise any power and
perform any function pertaining to its government and affairs, except as
limited by article VII, section 6 of the 1970 Illinois constitution; and
WHEREAS, the village president and board of trustees (the "village board")
determined that it is necessary, desirable and in the best interests of the
village, to produce a code of ordinances that will allow the general public and
those having business with the village, as well as the officers and employees
of the village, to have greater ease of access to the laws of the village; and
WHEREAS, the creation of a code of ordinances will promote a more efficient and
transparent operation of village government; and
WHEREAS, pursuant to statutory restrictions, title 11 (zoning regulations) of
the proposed code of ordinances can only be adopted after a duly noticed public
hearing before the plan commission is held and a findings of fact and
recommendation is prepared by the plan commission and forwarded to the village
president and board of trustees, so will be excluded from the adoption of the
balance of the proposed code of ordinances at this time.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED by the village president and board of trustees
of the village of Bloomingdale, DuPage County, Illinois, in the exercise of
their home rule authority, as follows:
   Section 1: From and after the date of passage of this ordinance, the village
code of the village of Bloomingdale, Illinois (the "village code"), containing
the attached compilation of village ordinances is hereby adopted as the
ordinances of the village of Bloomingdale, superseding all prior laws and
ordinances.
   Section 2: To the extent that any prior ordinances or portions thereof are
in conflict with or inconsistent with the code of ordinances, they are hereby
repealed, except ordinances passed after 2011-35 that are in conflict with the
village code shall take precedence over the village code provisions established
by this ordinance.
   Section 3: There is hereby adopted, as a method of perpetual codification,
the loose-leaf type of binding together with any and all supplements thereto,
either provided in-house or by a contractual service employed by the village,
whereby each newly adopted ordinance of a general and permanent nature
amending, altering, adding or deleting provisions of the village code is
identified by the proper catchline and is inserted in the proper place in each
of the official copies, one (1) copy of which shall be maintained in the office
of the village clerk, certified as to correctness and available for inspection
at any and all times that said office is regularly open.
   Section 4: All ordinances of a general nature included in the village code
shall be considered as a continuation of said ordinance provision and the fact
that some provisions have been deliberately eliminated by the village board
shall not serve to cause any interruption in the continuous effectiveness of
ordinances included in the village code. All ordinances of a special nature,
such as tax levy ordinances, bond ordinances, franchises, vacating ordinances
and annexation ordinances shall continue in full force and effect unless
specifically repealed or amended by a provision of the village code. Such
ordinances are not intended to be included in the village code.
   Section 5: This ordinance and the village code adopted by the same shall be
in full force and effect from and after its passage, approval and publication
in pamphlet form as provided by law.
PASSED AND APPROVED this 12th day of March, 2012.
   AYES:    Trustees Czernek, Von Huben, Bolen, Gebis, Hovde and King
   NAYS:    None
   ABSENT:    None
         /s/    
          Robert G. Iden, Village President
ATTEST:
/s/      
Irene M. Jones, Village Clerk
TITLE 1
ADMINISTRATION
CHAPTER 1
BLOOMINGDALE VILLAGE CODE
SECTION:
1-1-1: Title
1-1-2: Acceptance
1-1-3: Amendments
1-1-4: Code Alterations
1-1-1: TITLE:
Upon adoption by the village board of trustees, this code is hereby declared to
be and shall hereafter constitute the official village code of Bloomingdale.
This code of ordinances shall be known and cited as the BLOOMINGDALE VILLAGE
CODE and is hereby published by authority of the board of trustees and shall be
supplemented to incorporate the most recent legislation of the village as
provided in section
1-1-3 of this chapter. Any reference to the number of any section contained
herein shall be understood to refer to the position of the same number, its
appropriate chapter and title headings, and to the general penalty clause
relating thereto, as well as to the section itself, when reference is made to
this code by title in any legal documents. (2012 Code)
1-1-2: ACCEPTANCE:
This code, as hereby presented in printed form, shall hereafter be received
without further proof in all courts and in administrative tribunals of the
state as the ordinances of the village of general and permanent effect, except
the excluded ordinances enumerated in section
1-2-1 of this title. (2012 Code)
1-1-3: AMENDMENTS:
Any ordinance amending this code shall set forth the title, chapter and section
number of the section or sections to be amended, and this shall constitute
sufficient compliance with any statutory requirement pertaining to the
amendment or revision by ordinance of any part of this code. All such
amendments or revisions by ordinance shall be immediately forwarded to the
codifiers, and the said ordinance material shall be prepared for insertion in
its proper place in each copy of this code. Each such replacement page shall be
properly identified and shall be inserted in each individual copy of this code.
(2012 Code)
1-1-4: CODE ALTERATIONS:
It shall be deemed unlawful for any person to alter, change, replace or deface
in any way any section or any page of this code in such a manner that the
meaning of any phrase or order may be changed or omitted. Said code, while in
actual possession of officials and other interested persons, shall be and
remain the property of the village and shall be returned to the office of the
village clerk when directed so to do by order of the village board of trustees.
(2012 Code)
CHAPTER 2
SAVING CLAUSE
SECTION:
1-2-1: Repealed And Unaffected Ordinances
1-2-2: Conflicting Provisions
1-2-3: Prior Acts
1-2-4: Severability Clause
1-2-1: REPEALED AND UNAFFECTED ORDINANCES:
   A.   Repealed Ordinances: This code, from and after its effective date,
shall contain all of the provisions of a general nature pertaining to the
subjects herein enumerated and embraced. All prior ordinances pertaining to the
subjects treated by this code shall be deemed repealed from and after the
effective date of this code.
   B.   Unaffected Ordinances: All ordinances of a temporary or special nature
and all other ordinances pertaining to subjects not embraced in this code shall
remain in full force and effect unless herein repealed expressly or by
necessary implication. (2012 Code)
1-2-2: CONFLICTING PROVISIONS:
When any provision of this code conflicts with another provision of this code,
the provision that imposes the greater restriction shall be controlling. (2012
Code)
1-2-3: PRIOR ACTS:
Neither the enactment of this code nor the repeal of any ordinance or parts of
ordinances as affected by the adoption of this code shall be construed to
affect or abate any action or cause of action for violation of said prior
ordinance or ordinances. (2012 Code)
1-2-4: SEVERABILITY CLAUSE:
If any section, subsection, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase of this code,
or any codes or portions of codes adopted herein by reference, is for any
reason held to be unconstitutional or invalid or ineffective by any court of
competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity or
effectiveness of the remaining portions of this code, or any codes or portions
of codes adopted herein by reference. The village board hereby declares that it
would have passed each section, subsection, paragraph, sentence, clause or
phrase thereof irrespective of the fact that any one or more sections,
subsections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses or phrases be declared
unconstitutional, invalid or ineffective. (2012 Code)
CHAPTER 3
DEFINITIONS; INTERPRETATION
SECTION:
1-3-1: General Rules Of Interpretation
1-3-2: General Definitions
1-3-3: Catchlines
1-3-1: GENERAL RULES OF INTERPRETATION:
   A.   Liberal Construction: All general provisions, terms, phrases and
expressions contained in this code shall be liberally construed in order that
the true intent and meaning of the village president and board of trustees may
be fully carried out.
   B.   Minimum Requirements: In the interpretation and application of any
provision of this code, it shall be held to be the minimum requirements adopted
for the promotion of the public health, safety and general welfare. (2012 Code)
   C.   Computation Of Time: The time within which any act provided by law is
to be done shall be computed by excluding the first day and including the last,
unless the last day is Sunday or a legal holiday, and then it shall also be
excluded. If the day succeeding such Sunday or holiday is also a holiday or
Sunday, then such succeeding day shall also be included. (Ord. 80-3, 1-22-1980;
amd. 2012 Code)
   D.   Delegation Of Authority: Whenever a provision appears requiring the
department director or some other village officer to do some act or perform
some duty, it is to be construed to authorize the head of the department or
other officer to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the
required act or perform the duty unless the terms of the provision or section
specify otherwise.
   E.   Gender: A word importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be
applied to females and to firms, partnerships and corporations as well as to
males.
   F.   Joint Authority: All words giving a joint authority to three (3) or
more persons or officers shall be construed as giving such authority to a
majority of such persons or officers.
   G.   May; Shall: The word "may" is permissive; the word "shall" is
mandatory. (2012 Code)
   H.   Or; And: "Or" may be read "and", and "and" may be read "or" if the
sense requires it. (Ord. 80-3, 1-22-1980)
   I.   Nontechnical And Technical Words: Words and phrases shall be construed
according to the common and approved usage of the language, but technical words
and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate
meaning in law shall be construed and understood according to such meaning.
   J.   Number: A word importing the singular number only may extend and be
applied to several persons and things as well as to one person and thing.
   K.   Officers And Employees Generally: Whenever any officer or employee is
referred to by title only, such reference shall be construed as if followed by
the words "of the village of Bloomingdale".
   L.   Tense: Words used in the past or present tense include the future as
well as the past and present.
   M.   Ordinance: The word "ordinance" contained in the ordinances of the
village has been changed in the content of this code to "title", "chapter",
"section" and/or "subsection" or words of like import for organizational and
clarification purposes only. Such change to village ordinances is not meant to
amend passage and effective dates of such original ordinances. (2012 Code)
1-3-2: GENERAL DEFINITIONS:
Whenever the following words or terms are used in this code, they shall have
the meanings herein ascribed to them, unless the context makes such meaning
repugnant thereto:
AGENT: A person acting on behalf of another with authority conferred, either
expressly or by implication.
BOARD OF TRUSTEES: Unless otherwise indicated, the village board of trustees of
the village of Bloomingdale.
CODE: The village code of the village of Bloomingdale.
COUNTY: The county of DuPage, state of Illinois.
IN THE VILLAGE OR WITHIN THE VILLAGE: All territory over which the village now
has or shall hereafter acquire jurisdiction for any lawful purpose.
LICENSE: The permission granted for the carrying on of a business, profession
or occupation.
MONTH: A calendar month.
NUISANCE: Anything offensive to the sensibilities of reasonable persons, or any
act or activity creating a hazard which threatens the health and welfare of
inhabitants of the village, or any activity which, by its perpetuation, can
reasonably be said to have a detrimental effect on the property of a person or
persons within the community.
OATH; SWORN: The word "oath" shall be deemed to include an affirmation; the
word "sworn" shall be construed to include the word "affirmed".
OCCUPANT OR TENANT: Applied to a building or land, means any person who holds a
written or oral lease of or actually occupies the whole or part of such
building or land, either along or with others.
OFFENSE: Any act forbidden by any provision of this code or the omission of any
act required by the provisions of this code.
OPERATOR: The person who is in charge of any operation, business or profession.
OWNER: As applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint
owner, tenant in common, joint tenant or lessee of the whole or of a part of
such building or land.
PERSON: Any individual, partnership, corporation, joint stock association or
any city, or state, or any subdivision thereof and includes any trustee,
receiver, assignee or personal representative thereof.
PERSONAL PROPERTY: Includes every species of property, except "real estate" as
defined in this section.
PRECEDING; FOLLOWING: Next before and next after, respectively.
PROPERTY: Includes real and personal property.
REAL ESTATE: Includes lands, tenements and hereditaments and shall embrace all
chattels real.
RETAILER: Unless otherwise specifically defined, shall be understood to relate
to the sale of goods, merchandise, articles or things direct to the consumer.
RIGHT OF WAY: The privilege of the immediate use of the roadway or other
property.
SIDEWALK: That portion of a street between the curb lines or the lateral lines
of a roadway and the adjacent property lines, intended for the use of
pedestrians.
STATE: The state of Illinois.
STREET: The entire width between property lines of every way or place of
whatever nature when any part thereof is open to the use of the public, as a
matter of right, for purposes of vehicular traffic.
VILLAGE: The village of Bloomingdale, county of DuPage, state of Illinois.
WHOLESALER AND WHOLESALE DEALER: Unless otherwise specifically defined, shall
be understood to relate to the sale of goods, merchandise, articles or things
to persons who purchase for the purpose of resale.
WRITTEN, IN WRITING: May include printing and any other mode of representing
words and letters, but when the written signature of any person is required by
law on any official or public writing or bond, it shall be in the proper
handwriting of such person or, in case such person is unable to write, by such
person's proper mark.
YEAR: A calendar year, unless otherwise expressed. (Ord. 80-3, 1-22-1980; amd.
2012 Code)
1-3-3: CATCHLINES:
The catchlines of the several sections of this code are intended as mere
catchwords to indicate the content of the section and shall not be deemed or
taken to be titles of such sections, nor be deemed to govern, limit, modify or
in any manner affect the scope, meaning or intent of the provisions of any
division or section hereof, nor unless expressly so provided, shall they be so
deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or
reenacted. (2012 Code)
CHAPTER 4
GENERAL PENALTY
SECTION:
1-4-1: General Penalty
1-4-2: Application Of Provisions
1-4-3: Liability Of Officers
1-4-1: GENERAL PENALTY 1 :
   A.   General Penalty Imposed:
      1.   Fine; Imprisonment: Unless specifically provided elsewhere in this
Code, any person found to have been in violation of any of the terms and
provisions of this Code shall be fined in the amount not less than seventy five
dollars ($75.00) and not exceeding one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). No
imprisonment for failure to pay such fine, penalty or cost shall exceed six (6)
months for each offense. Each day that a violation continues shall be deemed to
be a separate offense. (Ord. 2019-07, 2-11-2019)
      2.   Conditional Discharge; Court Supervision; Restitution: In addition
to a fine described in subsection A1 of this section, the Circuit Court may
impose a period of conditional discharge as defined in 730 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/5-1-4 or court supervision as defined in 730 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/5-1-21 of the Criminal Code for a period of up to six (6) months, an
order of restitution, an order to perform community service, an order to
complete an education program and/or any other appropriate penalties or
conditions authorized in any section of this Code or stand alone ordinance or
any conditions for conditional discharge set forth in 730 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/5-6-3 or for court supervision in 730 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/
5-6-3.1 as the foregoing are amended from time to time.
      3.   Education Program:
         a.   A penalty imposed for violation of any provision of this Code may
include or consist of a requirement that the defendant complete an education
program; except, that a holder of a valid commercial driver's license who
commits a vehicle weight or size restriction violation shall not be required to
complete an education program under this subsection.
         b.   A low income individual required to complete an education program
under subsection A3a of this section who provides proof of eligibility for the
Federal Earned Income Tax credit under section 32 of the Internal Revenue Code
or the Illinois Earned Income Tax credit under 35 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/
212 shall not be required to pay any fee for participating in a required
education program.
      4.   Additional Remedies: The appropriate authorities of the Village may
take such other action as they deem proper to enforce the terms and provisions
of this Code including, without limitation, an action at law or in equity to
compel compliance with its terms.
      5.   Costs And Fees: Any person violating the terms or provisions of this
Code shall be subject, in addition to the penalties set out in this subsection,
to the payment of court costs and reasonable attorney fees.
      6.   Default In Payment: A default in the payment of a fine or any
installment of a fine may be collected by any means authorized for the
collection of monetary judgments. The Village Attorney may retain attorneys and
private collection agents for the purpose of collecting any default in payment
of any fine or installment of that fine. Any fees or costs incurred by the
Village with respect to attorneys or private collection agents retained by the
Village Attorney under this subsection shall be charged to the offender. (Ord.
2012-17, 4-9-2012)
   B.   Acts Consistent With Criminal Laws Of State: If, by the terms of an
ordinance, an act that would be consistent with the criminal laws of the State
is declared to be a misdemeanor, the penalty therefor shall be for a period of
incarceration in a penal institution other than a penitentiary not to exceed
six (6) months. The matter shall be prosecuted under the rules of criminal
procedure of the State, and the Village shall be required to establish guilt
beyond a reasonable doubt.
   C.   Limitation; Compliance With Statute: The provisions of subsection A of
this section notwithstanding, no penalty shall be greater than that established
by state statute for the same offense. (2012 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/1-2-1, 5/1-2-1.1.
1-4-2: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
   A.   Application Of Penalty: The penalty provided in this chapter shall be
applicable to every section of this code the same as though it were a part of
each and every separate section.
   B.   Acts Punishable Under Different Sections: In all cases where the same
offense is made punishable or is created by different clauses or sections of
this code, the prosecuting officer may elect under which to proceed, but not
more than one recovery shall be had against the same person for the same
offense; provided, that the revocation of a license or permit shall not be
considered a recovery or penalty so as to bar any other penalty being enforced.
   C.   Breach Of Provisions: Whenever the doing of any act or the omission to
do any act constitutes a breach of any section or provision of this code and
there shall be no fine or penalty specifically declared for such breach, the
provisions of this chapter shall apply. (2012 Code)
1-4-3: LIABILITY OF OFFICERS:
No provision of this code designating the duties of any officer or employee
shall be so construed as to make such officer or employee liable for any fine
or penalty provided for a failure to perform such duty, unless the intention of
the village board of trustees to impose such fine or penalty on such officer or
employee is specifically and clearly expressed in the section creating the
duty. (2012 Code)
CHAPTER 5
OFFICIAL AND CORPORATE PROVISIONS
SECTION:
1-5-1: Corporate Seal
1-5-2: Ordinances, Resolutions And Motions
1-5-1: CORPORATE SEAL:
   A.   Description: The seal now being used by and for the village, the
impression of which is in circular form, on the outer circle of which are the
words, "Village of Bloomingdale, DuPage County, Illinois", and within the inner
circle of which is the word "Seal", is hereby established and declared to have
been and to now and in the future be the official seal of the village, to be
used in all cases in which, by law and custom, it is necessary to use such a
seal to authenticate the corporate acts of the village. (Ord. 80-3, 1-22-1980;
amd. 2012 Code)
   B.   Custody And Use: The corporate seal shall be kept in the custody of the
village clerk and an impression thereof attached to all instruments, documents,
and other corporate acts which are required by statute or by direction of the
board of trustees to be authenticated by the corporate seal. (Ord. 80-3, 1-22-
1980)
1-5-2: ORDINANCES, RESOLUTIONS AND MOTIONS:
   A.   Style Of Enacting Ordinances: The enacting style of all ordinances
shall be: "Be it ordained by the President and Board of Trustees of the Village
of Bloomingdale.". (Ord. 80-3, 1-22-1980)
   B.   Approval Or Veto; Reconsideration Of And Passing Over:
      1.   All resolutions and motions: a) which create any liability against
the village; or b) which provide for the expenditure or appropriation of its
money; or c) to sell any village property, and all ordinances, passed by the
board of trustees shall be deposited with the village clerk. If the president
approves them, he shall sign them. Those of which he disapproves he shall
return to the board of trustees, with his written objections, at the next
regular meeting of the board of trustees occurring not less than five (5) days
after their passage. The president may disapprove of any one or more sums
appropriated in any ordinance or motion making an appropriation, and if so, the
remainder shall be effective. If the president fails to return any ordinance,
resolution, or motion of which he disapproves entirely, with his written
objections, within the designated time, it becomes effective without his
signature. (Ord. 80-3, 1-22-1980; amd. 2012 Code)
      2.   The board shall reconsider every resolution, motion or ordinance
returned thereto under subsection B1 of this section and may override the
president's veto by the affirmative vote of two-thirds (2/3) of all the
trustees elected to the board.
   C.   Passage:
      1.   Resolutions and motions: a) which create liability against the
village; or b) which provide for the expenditure or appropriation of its money;
or c) to sell village property, and ordinances, or any amendments to such
resolutions, motions, or ordinances, shall not be deemed passed until such
resolutions, motions, or ordinances are considered by and voted upon by the
board of trustees; except, that the reading and second consideration thereof
may be waived by a two-thirds (2/3) vote of the board of trustees.
      2.   When any such resolution, motion, ordinance or amendment considered
by the board of trustees receives a favorable vote from the board of trustees,
it shall be placed on the agenda and brought before the board of trustees by
the village clerk at the next regular meeting of the board of trustees for a
second vote upon said resolution, motion, ordinance, or amendment thereto
unless the second reading and consideration thereof has been waived as provided
herein.
      3.   The said resolution, motion, ordinance or amendment thereto shall be
deemed passed if it receives a passing vote at such second consideration. If
any said resolution, motion, ordinance, or amendment thereto fails to pass at
its first consideration, it shall be deemed to have failed its passage, and it
is not required that it be brought before the board at its next regular
meeting.
   D.   Reconsideration Of Vote At Special Meetings: No vote of the board shall
be reconsidered or rescinded at a special meeting unless there are present at
the special meeting as many trustees as were present when the vote was taken.
(Ord. 80-3, 1-22-1980)
   E.   Publication Of Ordinances: All ordinances of the village imposing any
fine, penalty, imprisonment or forfeiture or making any appropriation shall: 1)
be printed in book or pamphlet form, published by authority of the board; or 2)
be published at least once, within ten (10) days after passage, in one or more
newspapers with a general circulation in the village. No such ordinance shall
take effect until ten (10) days after it is so published; provided, that
ordinances establishing rules and regulations for the construction of buildings
or for the use of property, where such rules and regulations have been
previously printed in book or pamphlet form, may, by their terms, provide for
the adoption of such rules and regulations or portions thereof by references
thereto without further printing or publication. All other ordinances,
resolutions and motions shall take effect upon their passage unless they
otherwise provide. (Ord. 80-3, 1-22-1980; amd. 2012 Code)
   F.   Proof Of Ordinances:
      1.   The contents of all village ordinances, the date of passage and the
date of publication or posting, where required, may be proved by the
certificate of the village clerk, under the seal of the village.
      2.   Whenever village ordinances are printed in book or pamphlet form,
and purport to be published by authority of the board of trustees, such book or
pamphlet shall be prima facie evidence of the contents, passage and legal
publication of such ordinances, as of the dates mentioned in such book or
pamphlet, in all courts and administrative tribunals. (Ord. 80-3, 1-22-1980)
CHAPTER 6
VILLAGE PRESIDENT AND BOARD OF TRUSTEES
SECTION:
1-6-1: Village Board Of Trustees
1-6-2: Village President
1-6-3: Meetings
1-6-4: Rules And Order Of Business
1-6-5: Committees
1-6-1: VILLAGE BOARD OF TRUSTEES:
   A.   Function: The village shall be governed by the village board.
   B.   Composition: The village board shall consist of a village president and
six (6) trustees.
   C.   Voting Rights:
      1.   Trustees: Each trustee of the board shall have the right to vote on
all questions coming before the board unless he is directly interested therein.
      2.   President: The president shall preside at all meetings of the board
and shall not vote except in case of a tie or unless it is necessary for a
majority or statutory approval or on a matter which he is given statutory
authority to vote.
   D.   Powers:
      1.   Improvements: The board shall, in addition to all powers and duties
already conferred thereon, make all orders for doing the work or the making of
any improvements within the village.
      2.   Revenue And Expense: The board shall levy all taxes, apportion and
appropriate all funds and audit and allow all bills, accounts, claims and
payrolls and order the payment thereof.
      3.   Contracts: The board shall make or authorize the making of all
contracts with the village, the same to be made either by ordinance or
resolution adopted by the board. (Ord. 80-3, 1-22-1980)
      4.   Authority Over Committees, Department Directors And Supervisors: All
committees, department directors and supervisors are subject to the authority
of the board of trustees. Their acts and decisions are subject to review,
reconsideration, and final approval by the board. Such department directors and
supervisors may be required, at the discretion of the board, to make such
report in writing concerning the affairs of their function or assignment as the
board may deem necessary. (Ord. 80-3, 1-22-1980; amd. 2012 Code)
      5.   Removal Of Officers: Any appointive officer shall be subject to
removal by the board of trustees at any time, and all appointments shall be
made upon such condition, and when so removed, the salary of such person shall
cease. All suspended appointees shall have the right to appeal to the village
board of trustees from the suspension decrees of the president or other
officer. The action of the board of trustees shall be final.
      6.   Rules And Order Of Business: The board shall adopt rules governing
its order of business and prescribing the manner in which legislation shall be
considered, which rules and order of business shall not be inconsistent with
law and the ordinances of the village.
      7.   Creation, Discontinuance Of Offices: The board shall have the power,
by ordinance, from time to time, to create, fill and discontinue offices and
employment, and to add, assign or transfer to any officer or employee new
duties from time to time.
      8.   Changes In Compensation: The village board may, by ordinance,
prescribe, limit or change the compensation of all officers and employees.
(Ord. 80-3, 1-22-1980)
1-6-2: VILLAGE PRESIDENT 1 :
   A.   Powers And Duties:
      1.   The president shall have all the powers and perform all the duties
hereinafter set forth and as are provided by the laws of the state of Illinois
or by the village ordinances. He shall be the chief executive officer and
representative of the village. Among other things, he shall perform the
following duties:
         a.   Preside at all regular and special meetings of the board of
trustees, unless unavoidably prevented.
         b.   Nominate persons to fill the appointive offices of the village.
         c.   Investigate all matters pertaining to the interests of the
village and well being of the residents.
         d.   Countersign all commissions, licenses and permits authorized by
statute or village ordinance. (Ord. 80-3, 1-22-1980)
         e.   Sign all contracts and warrants on behalf of the village,
approved by resolution. (Ord. 80-3, 1-22-1980; amd. 2012 Code)
         f.   Generally, be charged with the responsibility for the proper
conduct of the village affairs and the enforcement of all ordinances of the
village.
      2.   The village president shall submit to the board of trustees a report
relative to the affairs of the village, and he shall recommend for
consideration by the board such measures as he may deem expedient. (Ord. 80-3,
1-22-1980)
   B.   President Pro Tem: If a temporary absence from the village or
disability of the president incapacitates him from the performance of his
duties, but does not create a vacancy in the office, the board of trustees
shall elect one of its members to act as village president pro tem. The village
president pro tem, during this absence or disability, shall perform the duties
and possess all the rights and powers of the village president but shall not be
entitled to vote as president pro tem and trustee. (Ord. 80-3, 1-22-1980; amd.
2012 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See section 1-8-2 of this title for bond requirements.
1-6-3: MEETINGS:
   A.   Regular Meetings: The regular meetings of the board of trustees shall
be held on the second and fourth Mondays of each month at seven thirty o'clock
(7:30) P.M. (Ord. 80-20, 4-8-1980)
   B.   Special Meetings:
      1.   The president or any two (2) trustees, upon forty eight (48) hours'
notice, may call special meetings of the board by giving written or printed
notice at the usual place of business or place of residence of each member
before the hour of holding such meeting. Such notice shall state the object of
such meeting and may be served by any member of the police department or any
member of the board or other officer of the village who shall certify that he
has served said notice by showing in what manner the same has been served. Such
notices and copies thereof shall be prepared by the village clerk when
requested. (Ord. 80-3, 1-22-1980; amd. 2012 Code)
      2.   At any regular meeting, a majority of the village board may call a
special meeting, and said special meeting shall be noted by the village clerk
in the minutes of that meeting.
      3.   Special meetings shall be held at such location as is contained in
the notice of said special meeting.
   C.   Quorum; Voting:
      1.   Four (4) members of the board, including the president, shall
constitute a quorum to do business, but no ordinance shall be passed except
upon the favorable vote of a majority of the elected members. (Ord. 80-3, 1-22-
1980)
      2.   Upon every vote, the "ayes" and "nays" shall be called and recorded,
and every motion, resolution or ordinance, if the president or any member shall
require it, shall be reduced to writing and read, unless waived, before a vote
shall be taken thereon. Every trustee present shall vote thereon unless the
board shall, for good reason shown, excuse him from voting or unless he is
directly interested therein, in which case, he shall not be entitled to vote.
(Ord. 80-3, 1-22-1980; amd. 2012 Code)
   D.   Temporary Chair: In the absence of the village president, acting
village president, or village president pro tem, the board of trustees may
elect a trustee to act as a temporary chair. He shall have only the powers of a
presiding officer and a right to vote in his capacity as trustee on any
ordinance, resolution, or motion. (Ord. 80-3, 1-22-1980)
   E.   Public Participation:
      1.   Rules: The following rules shall apply to public participation at
regular meetings of the village board of trustees and the village board of
trustees acting as a standing committee of the whole or a special committee of
the whole (hereinafter referred to as "board meetings"):
         a.   Public participation at board meetings is encouraged. A period of
time at the beginning of each board meeting shall be made available for public
comments regarding items on the agenda or related to any other village
ordinances, policies or operations (hereinafter referred to as "audience
participation").
         b.   A period of time at the end of each meeting shall also be
available for public comments regarding items on the agenda only (hereinafter
referred to as "comments from the public").
         c.   A person shall be permitted to speak upon being recognized by the
village president or the acting chair. The person shall stand (if possible),
state his/her name and address prior to making comments, and limit speaking to
no more than five (5) minutes, unless additional time is granted by the village
president or acting chair. Each person will be permitted to speak only once
during audience participation and again during comments from the public.
         d.   All speakers shall address their comments to the village
president or acting chair. The village president or acting chair may request
that the appropriate member of the board or staff respond to the comment.
         e.   The village president or acting chair shall preserve order and
decorum and shall decide all questions of order.
         f.   When addressing the board, members, administrative officers and
other persons permitted to speak shall confine their remarks to the matter at
hand and avoid repetitious commentary, personal remarks, the impugning of
motives, and merely contentious or disruptive statements.
         g.   If any person indulges in such remarks or otherwise engages in
conduct injurious to the harmony of the board and the meeting, the village
president or acting chair may immediately terminate the opportunity to speak.
This decision is at the discretion of the village president or acting chair or
upon the affirmative vote of two-thirds (2/3) of the trustees present. Any
person, except a member of the board, who engages in disorderly conduct during
a meeting may be ejected from the meeting upon motion passed by a majority of
the trustees present.
      2.   Citizens' Guide Available At Each Meeting: The following shall be
printed and made available to the public at each board meeting:
CITIZENS' GUIDE TO ADDRESSING THE BOARD:
Anyone wishing to speak under the agenda item entitled "Audience Participation"
or "Comments from the Public" shall adhere to the following guidelines:
1. A person shall be permitted to speak upon being recognized by the village
president or acting chair. Please stand (if possible) and approach the podium,
announce your name and address before commencing. All comments under "Audience
Participation" or "Comments from the Public" are limited to five (5) minutes,
and each person shall only be permitted to speak once.
2. All speakers shall address their comments to the village president or acting
chair.
3. The village president or acting chair shall preserve order and decorum and
shall decide all questions of order.
4. When addressing the board, members, administrative officers and other
persons permitted to speak shall confine their remarks to the matter at hand
and avoid personal remarks, the impugning of motives, and merely contentious or
disruptive statements. If any person indulges in such remarks or otherwise
engages in conduct injurious to the harmony of the board and the meeting, the
village president or acting chair may immediately terminate the opportunity to
speak. This decision is at the discretion of the village president or acting
chair or upon the affirmative vote of two-thirds (2/3) of the trustees present.
Any person, except a member of the board, who engages in disorderly conduct
during a meeting may be ejected from the meeting upon motion passed by a
majority of the trustees present.
5. Please do not repeat comments that have already been made by others.
(Ord. 2011-22, 6-13-2011)
      3.   Exemptions From Rules: The rules and regulations included in this
section do not apply to the meetings of the planning and zoning commission,
police pension board, board of fire and police commissioners, or any other
appointed board and commission, as these bodies have statutory requirements
concerning public hearings and other public meetings. (Ord. 2011-22, 6-13-2011;
amd. Ord. 2014-48, 10-27-2014)
   F.   Electronic Attendance At Meetings: The rules and policies for
electronic attendance at meetings are located at section
2-0-1 of this code. (Ord. 2014-51, 11-10-2014)
1-6-4: RULES AND ORDER OF BUSINESS:
The following rules for the government of the meetings of the board of trustees
are hereby adopted:
   A.   Order Of Business:
      1.   Regular Meetings: The order of business at all regular meetings
shall be determined by roll call vote at each meeting. The agenda for each
meeting may include the following items but not in any particular sequence:
         a.   Call to order and calling the roll of the trustees.
         b.   Pledge Of Allegiance.
         c.   Approval of minutes of any regular meeting and special meeting.
         d.   Approval of the directive to pay, and consideration of, bills
against the village.
         e.   Communications and correspondence, reading and referring
petitions and communications.
         f.   Reports of committees.
         g.   Reports of the administrative staff.
         h.   Old business.
         i.   New business.
         j.   Discussion from the floor.
         k.   Adjournment.
      2.   Special Meetings: The order of business at special meetings shall be
as follows:
         a.   Call to order and calling of the roll of the trustees.
         b.   Consideration of the object of the meeting.
   B.   Rules Of Procedure:
      1.   Unless otherwise provided by statute, meetings of the board of
trustees shall be conducted in accordance with "Robert's Rules Of Order".
      2.   The president shall decide all questions of order, subject to an
appeal to the board; and in all cases, where these rules are not applicable,
the board of trustees shall be governed by parliamentary law, as laid down in
"Robert's Rules Of Order".
   C.   Suspension Of Rules: The rules of the board of trustees, other than
those prescribed by statute, may be suspended during any one meeting by a
majority vote of the members present. (Ord. 80-3, 1-22-1980)
   D.   Written Resolutions And Ordinances: All resolutions and ordinances
shall be reduced to writing and handed to the clerk and read by him, unless
waived, before being presented to the board of trustees for action. (Ord. 80-3,
1-22-1980; amd. 2012 Code)
   E.   President And Trustees To Attend Meetings: It shall be the duty of the
president and board of trustees to attend every meeting of the board of
trustees and their respective committee meetings unless unavoidably detained.
   F.   Referring Documents: All ordinances, petitions, resolutions, orders,
and communications to the village shall be referred by the president or
presiding officer to the proper committee, officer or employee.
   G.   Committee Reports: Each standing and special committee shall make a
report in the committee minutes or orally on the state of the matters before
that committee. (Ord. 80-3, 1-22-1980)
1-6-5: COMMITTEES:
   A.   General Committees: The following trustee assignments shall be made by
the president:
Police and community relations.
Planning, zoning and environmental concerns.
Facilities and golf course.
Traffic and street infrastructure.
Finance, personnel and administration.
Intergovernmental relations.
(Ord. 80-3, 1-22-1980; amd. 2012 Code)
   B.   Other Committees: The president shall appoint such other and further
committees as may be necessary to properly carry on the business of the
village. Written minutes shall be made of all committee meetings and submitted
to the board of trustees at the next regular meeting.
   C.   Committee Of The Whole: In addition, a committee of the whole shall
consist of the village president, the members of the board of trustees, and the
village administrator, if there be one. The chair of said committee shall be
the village president. The village president shall be an ex officio member of
all committees. (Ord. 80-3, 1-22-1980)
CHAPTER 7
VILLAGE CLERK 1
SECTION:
1-7-1: Elected Official
1-7-2: Duties
1-7-3: Deputy Clerk
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  1-8-2 of this title for bond requirements.
1-7-1: ELECTED OFFICIAL:
The village clerk is an elected village official, and shall serve a four (4)
year term of office and until a successor is elected and qualified, as provided
by state statute. (Ord. 2012-40, 11-12-2012)
1-7-2: DUTIES:
In addition to the statutory duties and those contained elsewhere in this code,
the village clerk shall:
   A.   Attend all meetings of the board of trustees; and post notice of and
record all proceedings of the board of trustees; and make available for public
inspection that record, within seven (7) days after approval by the board of
trustees.
   B.   Tape, or make a digital recording of, all closed meetings of the board
of trustees pursuant to the Illinois open meetings act 1 , secure such recorded
media in a safe place where it shall be kept in confidentiality, and otherwise
assure that the requirements of the open meetings act are met with respect to
their release and destruction. If the village clerk cannot attend a closed
meeting for whatever reason, the village clerk, a deputy village clerk, or
another designee of the clerk shall be responsible for assuring compliance with
the requirements of this subsection. The person taking minutes for such meeting
shall record the meeting and then provide the village clerk with the original
recorded media for security thereof. No copies of such recorded media shall be
made by any person other than the village clerk, or an authorized deputy clerk.
   C.   Keep a record of all ordinances and resolutions of the village in a
book or books provided for that purpose. For every ordinance requiring posting
or recording, the clerk shall, when so required, have noted thereon the date of
such posting or recording, and to make a certificate of such posting or
recording and attach the same to the original ordinance kept in the records of
the village.
   D.   Seal and attest all ordinances, resolutions and contracts of the
village, certain licenses and permits, and other such documents as shall
require this formality. The seal of the village may be mechanically or
digitally printed on certain licenses, permits and other such documents, so
that a manual seal by the clerk is not necessary, but all documents with a
mechanical or digital seal, as provided herein, shall nevertheless be
considered officially sealed village documents.
   E.   Serve certain notices, either by personal service, by publication or
posting, required by statute, local ordinance, or by order of the president or
board of trustees to be served and in the manner by law required, unless
notices are expressly ordered to be served by another village official.
   F.   Provide the election material for village residents running in village
elections.
   G.   Provide facilities for local voter registration.
   H.   Keep a complete and accurate file of the official papers of the village
so that ready access thereto and use thereof may be had by any properly
authorized elected official, village officer, or village staff member.
   I.   Countersign, in writing, all contracts, bonds, other agreements, or
evidence of indebtedness, of the village made in the name of the village, and
by the authority of the village president and board of trustees.
   J.   If created by the board of trustees, keep a list of all village board
committees, and a record of the business brought before them.
   K.   The clerk shall be the custodian of the village seal and shall affix
its impression on documents whenever this is required, pursuant to subsection D
of this section.
   L.   Perform all, and such duties as are, from time to time, imposed by the
village president or board of trustees.
   M.   Appoint a deputy clerk or deputy clerks pursuant to section
1-7-3 of this chapter. (Ord. 2012-40, 11-12-2012)
 
Notes
1 2. 5 ILCS 120/1 et seq.
1-7-3: DEPUTY CLERK:
   A.   Appointment; Restrictions: The village clerk shall have the authority
to appoint one deputy village clerk to discharge the functions and duties of
the office of village clerk, who need not be a resident of the village;
provided, that no such appointment shall be made unless and until funding for
the deputy village clerk position described in this section has been approved
by the village board in the fiscal year budget for the year of any such
proposed appointment. The deputy village clerk position identified in this
section shall be a part time, nonexempt position in village service, or be a
full time, nonexempt position undertaken by a current employee whose duties in
village service are combined with the duties of deputy village clerk.
   B.   Additional Deputy Clerks: For administrative convenience and to provide
better service to the general public, the village clerk shall have the
authority to appoint other deputy village clerks, in addition to the deputy
clerk described in subsection A of this section. Such additional deputy village
clerks need not be residents of the village, but shall be employees of the
village, and shall discharge certain functions and duties of the office of the
village clerk without any compensation other than their budgeted salary as a
village employee, regardless of whether they are a full time, exempt/salaried
employee, a full time, nonexempt/hourly employee or a part time, nonexempt/
hourly employee.
   C.   Duties: The deputy village clerk, under the general supervision of the
village clerk and village administrator, shall:
      1.   Maintain custody of all village records;
      2.   Publish and post notices of all public meetings and copies of
resolutions and ordinances adopted by the village board when appropriate or
directed;
      3.   Maintain the corporate seal and certify the authenticity of all
copies of village documents;
      4.   Serve as local registrar of all vital statistics kept by the
village;
      5.   Attend meetings of the village president and board of trustees when
the village clerk is unavailable and keep a record of their proceedings; (Ord.
2011-32, 9-12-2011)
      6.   Register voters; (Ord. 2011-32, 9-12-2011; amd. 2012 Code)
      7.   Receive developer escrow application fees; and
      8.   Perform such functions or duties as assigned by the village clerk or
village administrator. (Ord. 2011-32, 9-12-2011)
CHAPTER 8
VILLAGE OFFICERS AND PERSONNEL
SECTION:
