1-8-1: PROCEDURES MANUAL ADOPTED:
   A.   The manual on file with the Village Clerk entitled "Bloomingdale
Procedures Manual" is hereby adopted as the official manual of the Village
governing certain employee relations.
   B.   Copies of said manual are to be directed forthwith to the Village
Administrator for immediate implementation in all departments of Village
government. (Ord. 76-19A, 4-26-1976)
1-8-2: BONDS:
   A.   Required; Amounts: The following Village officials shall obtain a
public officials bond in the following amounts:
      1.   Village President: Equal to the minimum amount required by the
Statutes of the State of Illinois.
      2.   Village Clerk: Equal to the minimum amount required by the Statutes
of the State of Illinois.
      3.   Village Administrator: Ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00). (Ord. 94-
29, 6-13-1994)
      4.   Village Engineer: Ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00). (Ord. 94-29, 6-
13-1994; amd. 2012 Code; Ord. 2017-42, 11-13-2017)
      5.   Finance Director-Treasurer: Three (3) times the latest Federal
census population of the Village or any subsequent census figures used for
Motor Fuel Tax purposes. (Ord. 94-29, 6-13-1994; amd. 2012 Code)
      6.   Chief of Police: Ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00).
      7.   Building Commissioner: Ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00).
   B.   Conditions: All bonds required by this section shall be payable to the
Village, conditioned upon the faithful performance of the duties of the office
and the payment of all monies received by each such officer according to the
law and the ordinances of the Village. (Ord. 94-29, 6-13-1994)
   C.   Filing: All bonds obtained pursuant to this section shall be filed with
the Village Clerk, except the bond of the Village Clerk, which shall be filed
with the Village Finance Director-Treasurer. (Ord. 94-29, 6-13-1994; amd. 2012
Code)
   D.   Payment By Village: All bonds required by this section will be paid by
the Village. (Ord. 94-29, 6-13-1994)
1-8-3: COMPENSATION FOR ELECTED OFFICIALS:
   A.   Village Trustees:
      1.   Each Village Trustee shall receive the following compensation:
 
Effective Date Compensation
May 1, 2007    $90.00 for each Board of Trustees or Committee of the Whole
               meeting attended, with a maximum of $360.00 per month
May 1, 2025    $500.00 per month
 
      2.   All Village Trustees who are elected in the April 2007 Municipal
election to fill a four (4) year term of office and all Trustees elected or
appointed thereafter shall receive compensation of ninety dollars ($90.00) for
each and every official special meeting attended, with a maximum of twelve (12)
such official special meetings per fiscal year as compensation for attendance
at such official special meetings by the Trustee. Such special meetings are
duly called and posted as standing committee of the whole or Village Board
meetings, and are called in addition to those meetings published on a yearly
basis as required by law. A continued regular meeting shall not constitute a
special meeting.
   B.   Village President:
      1.   The Village President shall receive the following compensation:
 
Effective Date Compensation
May 1, 2025    $28,000.00 per year paid in twelve equal monthly payments.
 
   C.   Village Clerk:
      1.   The Village Clerk shall receive the following compensation:
 
Effective Date Compensation
May 1, 2017    $200.00 for each Board of Trustees or Committee of the Whole
               meeting attended, with a maximum of $600.00 per month.
May 1, 2025    $975.00 per month
 
   D.   Compensation Increases: On May 1 of every year, the compensation of the
Village President/Liquor Control Commissioner, the Village Clerk and the
Village Trustees shall be increased by the lesser of three percent (3%) or the
percentage increase in the Consumer Price Index for the twelve (12) month
period preceding May 1. The term "Consumer Price Index" shall mean the Chicago
area Consumer Price Index for all urban consumers for all items as published by
the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the United States Department of Labor or any
successor index created by the Department of Labor as a substitute index that
measures the average change in prices of goods and services purchased by urban
consumers. The most recent consumer price index available on May 1 of each year
shall be used in applying this subsection to any increases in compensation. If
the index is a negative number, then there shall be no decrease in the
compensation, but the compensation shall remain the same as the previous fiscal
year. Amounts for monthly and per meeting compensation shall be rounded to the
nearest whole dollar
   E.   Payment Of Compensation: Compensation shall be paid in the form of a
monthly stipend check, in accordance with the Village's usual and customary
payroll practices. (Ord. 2006-36, 8-14-2006; amd. Ord. 2012-44, 11-12-2012;
Ord. 2016-44, 10-24-2016; Ord. 2022-47, 11-14-2022; Ord. 2024-37, 8-26-2024)
1-8-4: INDEMNIFICATION:
   A.   It is found and declared by the village president and board of trustees
("village") as follows:
      1.   The village has the power to indemnify its officials, both elected
and appointed, pursuant to law. (Ord. 92-78, 11-23-1992)
      2.   The term "officials", as used in this section, shall mean the
president and trustees, the village administrator, department directors and
appointed committee and commission members, as well as all other officers of
the village, whether or not currently serving. (Ord. 92-78, 11-23-1992; amd.
2012 Code)
      3.   It is in the best interest of the village to provide for the
indemnification of its officials, both elected and appointed, against claims,
expenses and liabilities to which such persons may be subject by reason of
their having acted in their capacity as a public official.
   B.   The village shall indemnify any official who was or is a party, or may
become a party, to any threatened, pending or completed action, suit or
proceeding, whether civil, administrative or investigative, by reason of any
act or omission, error, misstatement or misleading statement, or neglect or
breach of duty or any other action which could reasonably be construed to have
been committed, attempted or allegedly committed or attempted by such person in
the discharge of his or her duties in his or her capacity as an official, both
elected and appointed, against expenses (including attorney fees), judgments
and amounts paid in settlement actually and reasonably incurred by him or her
in connection with such action, suit or proceeding, if such person acted in
good faith in a manner in which he or she reasonably believed was in the best
interests of the village. This indemnification shall not apply to any claim,
suit, action or proceeding:
      1.   Which is for the return by any such official, both elected and
appointed, of any remuneration paid in fact to him or her without the previous
approval of the village if it shall be determined by judgment or other final
adjudication that such remuneration is in violation of law or if such
remuneration is to be repaid to the village under a settlement agreement.
      2.   Which is for an accounting of profits made from a purchase or sale
by such official, both elected and appointed, of village property for any
transaction prohibited by the village ethics ordinance 1 .
      3.   Which is brought about or contributed to by the fraudulent or
dishonest acts of such official, both elected and appointed, if a judgment or
other final adjudication adverse to such official establishes that acts of
active and deliberate dishonesty were committed or attempted by such official
with actual dishonest purpose and intent and were material to the cause of
action so adjudicated.
      4.   Which is brought about or contributed to by any criminal activities
of such official, and there has been a judicial determination of said criminal
activities.
      5.   For which the village is not authorized by law to provide
indemnification to the official, either elected or appointed.
      6.   With reference to any of the aforementioned enumerated items, a
presumption shall exist that indemnification shall apply unless a judicial
finding to the contrary is made.
   C.   The termination of any action, suit or proceeding, contrary to the best
interests of the official, by judgment, order, settlement or other resolution
shall not create a presumption that the official did not act in good faith in a
manner in which he or she reasonably believed was in the best interests of the
village. To the extent that an official has been successful, on the merits or
otherwise, in the defense of any action, suit or proceeding or in the defense
of any claim which qualifies herein for indemnification, such person shall be
indemnified against expenses (including attorney fees) actually and reasonably
incurred by such person in connection therewith. However, the village shall not
withhold payment of attorney fees until the conclusion of any legal
proceedings, but shall pay the attorney fees of the official on a timely basis.
   D.   The village shall indemnify only those officials, either elected or
appointed, from whom or with respect to whom the village has received written
notice of a claim. To the extent practicable, any notice from such official
shall be mailed as soon as practicable and shall identify the official seeking
the indemnification and contain information with respect to the time, place and
circumstances of the claim, the names and addresses of any injured persons or
other claimants and the names of any available witnesses. In the case where
legal proceedings have been commenced, indemnification may be denied if the
official fails to mail to the village, within twenty (20) days after receiving
service of process, a copy of such process relating to a claimed wrongful act
unless: 1) the village has otherwise received a copy of, or written notice of,
such process; or 2) the failure to notify within such twenty (20) day period
does not adversely impact upon the village's ability to defend against such
claim. Notice of the claim shall be made in writing to the village clerk.
   E.   The village shall indemnify the official for any damages, expenses,
court costs and legal fees incurred in connection with any defense of or
settlement of a claim, action or proceeding where such settlement has been
approved in advance by the village, or where the village refuses or fails to
approve such settlement, such settlement is deemed to be reasonable by
independent legal counsel chosen by both the village and the official.
   F.   Any indemnification pursuant to this section shall be made by the
village upon a determination that indemnification of the person is required by
this section. Such determination shall be made: 1) by the president and board
of trustees by a majority vote of a quorum of the board who were not parties to
such claim, suit, action or proceeding; or 2) if such quorum is not obtainable
or, even if obtainable, where a majority of a quorum of the board fails to
approve the indemnification, by independent legal counsel chosen by both the
claimant and the village board.
   G.   Any official against whom any action, suit or proceeding is brought may
employ his or her own attorney; provided, that such attorney is reasonably
acceptable to the village; and provided further, that the costs of such
attorney shall not be paid by the village unless the village attorney or
independent counsel for the village shall have advised the village that such
official's interests should not be represented by the same counsel that
represents the village in such action, suit or proceeding.
   H.   The indemnification provided herein shall be in addition to and not
exclusive of any other indemnity or insurance or other protection to which the
indemnitee may be entitled. The indemnification provided herein shall be
payable whether or not the village has obtained insurance therefor and, in the
case of the death of the indemnitee, shall inure to the benefit of his or her
heirs or successors. (Ord. 92-78, 11-23-1992)
 
Notes
1 1. See chapter 10 of this title.
1-8-5: EQUAL EMPLOYMENT POLICY:
   All persons shall have the right to be free from discrimination on the basis
of race, color, creed, national ancestry and sex in hiring and promotion
practices of any employer.
(Ord. 77-58, 11-28-1977; amd. 2012 Code)
The village hereby recognizes that the absence of overt discrimination does not
in itself assure equal opportunity to women and minority groups, and that other
factors such as poverty, inferior education, and traditional recruitment or
employment practices also hinder the minority applicant. The affirmative action
program, with its result oriented procedures and specified goals, is intended
to combat those handicaps. Furthermore, through the efforts of the village
administrator, there will be a continuing process of review of the hiring
practices, the administrative procedures and the promotion structure of the
village. (Ord. 77-58, 11-28-1977)
1-8-6: PARTICIPATION IN ILLINOIS MUNICIPAL RETIREMENT FUND:
The village does hereby elect to participate in the Illinois municipal
retirement fund, effective January 1, 1974. (Ord. 73-45, 9-26-1973)
ARTICLE A. FINANCE DIRECTOR-TREASURER 1
SECTION:
1-8A-1: Office Created; Appointment And Term
1-8A-2: Powers And Duties
1-8A-3: Special Assessment Fund
1-8A-4: Drawing Warrants; Transfer Of Funds
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  1-8-2 of this chapter for bond requirements.
1-8A-1: OFFICE CREATED; APPOINTMENT AND TERM:
There is hereby created the office of finance director-treasurer. The finance
director-treasurer shall be appointed by the village president, with the advice
and consent of the board of trustees. The finance director-treasurer shall have
a term of office of one year and until his successor has been chosen and has
qualified. (Ord. 80-12, 2-26-1980; amd. 2012 Code)
1-8A-2: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   In addition to the duties specifically delegated to the finance
director-treasurer by this code, the director of finance-treasurer shall have
all duties and powers which are assigned by any statute of the state of
Illinois or any code, ordinance or resolution of the village to the office of
village treasurer and shall serve ex officio in such capacity concurrently with
his full time employment as director of the finance department.
   B.   The finance director-treasurer shall:
      1.   Perform such duties as may be prescribed for the village treasurer
by statute or ordinance.
      2.   Receive all monies paid into the village, whether directly from the
person paying the money or from the hands of such other officer or employee as
may receive it, and he shall pay out money only on vouchers or orders properly
signed by the village president and clerk.
      3.   Review all claims for reimbursement against the village and submit a
list of all outstanding claims to the finance, personnel and administration
committee for their consideration, together with his report as to the status of
the claims.
      4.   Prepare and file all fiscal, financial, and tax reports, documents,
and materials as may be required of the village to be presented to public
agencies of the federal, state, and county governments, and to be presented to
such financial institutions as may be doing business with the village.
      5.   On or before June 15 of each year, submit to the board of trustees a
report of his estimate, as nearly as may be, of the money necessary to defray
the expenses of the village during the current fiscal year. For the purpose of
making this report, the finance director-treasurer shall require all officers
of the village to submit statements of the condition and expenses of their
offices or departments; and any proposed improvements and the estimated expense
thereof; a statement of all unperformed contracts; and the amount of all
unexpended appropriations of the preceding year. His report shall also:
         a.   Classify the objects and purposes of such estimated expenditures
and the amounts required for each;
         b.   Show the aggregate income of the preceding fiscal year, from all
sources;
         c.   Show the amount of liability on which interest is to be paid;
         d.   Show the bonds and debts due and payable and the dates when such
are due and payable; and
         e.   Give such other information regarding the financial situation of
the village as the board of trustees may require.
      6.   Deposit the village funds in such depositories as may be selected
from time to time as provided by law and keep the deposit of the village monies
separate and distinct from his own monies. The finance director-treasurer shall
not use village monies for personal or private use.
      7.   Keep such books, accounts, and records as may be required by statute
or ordinance, and establish, supervise, and maintain the financial record
system of the village. The records, books, and accounts of the finance
director-treasurer shall show, among other things, all monies received by him
showing the source from which it is received and the purpose for which it is
paid. (Ord. 80-12, 2-26-1980; amd. 2012 Code)
1-8A-3: SPECIAL ASSESSMENT FUND:
All monies received on any special assessment shall be held by the finance
director-treasurer as a special fund to be applied only to the payment of the
improvement, or bonds and vouchers issued therefor, together with interest
thereon, for which the assessment was made, and such money shall be used for no
other purpose unless to reimburse the village for money expended for such
improvements. Payment on bonds or vouchers shall be made in accordance with the
statutes and the law, and the finance director-treasurer shall keep his books
and accounts in such a manner so that proper prorations in payments of
principal and interest can be made and ascertained. (Ord. 80-12, 2-26-1980;
amd. 2012 Code)
1-8A-4: DRAWING WARRANTS; TRANSFER OF FUNDS:
   A.   All warrants drawn on the finance director-treasurer must be signed by
the president and countersigned by the clerk, stating the particular fund or
appropriation to which the same is chargeable and the person to whom payable,
and no money shall be otherwise paid except as may be provided by statute.
   B.   Money shall not be transferred by the finance director-treasurer from
one fund to another after it has been received by him, nor appropriated to any
other purpose than that for which has been collected or paid, except as may be
ordered by the president and board of trustees in manner and form prescribed by
statute. (Ord. 80-12, 2-26-1980; amd. 2012 Code)
ARTICLE B. VILLAGE ATTORNEY
SECTION:
1-8B-1: Office Created; Qualifications
1-8B-2: Appointment; Legal Advisor
1-8B-3: Duties
1-8B-4: Compensation
1-8B-1: OFFICE CREATED; QUALIFICATIONS:
There is hereby created the office of village attorney, which office shall be
held by an attorney or firm of attorneys admitted to the bar and licensed to
practice law in the state. (Ord. 71-79, 9-8-1971)
1-8B-2: APPOINTMENT; LEGAL ADVISOR:
The village president may appoint and retain the village attorney to act as
legal advisor to the village, and said village attorney shall render advice on
all legal questions affecting the village, as the board of trustees may request
from time to time. (Ord. 71-79, 9-8-1971; amd. 2012 Code)
1-8B-3: DUTIES:
   A.   Prepare Documents: The village attorney shall prepare all ordinances
and resolutions required by the board of trustees, and shall draft and/or
supervise the content of any contracts, leases, or other documents and
instruments to which the village may be a party.
   B.   Attend Meetings: The village attorney shall attend all regular and
special meetings of the board of trustees and such meetings of boards and
commissions of the village or committees of the board of trustees as he shall
be directed by the board of trustees. (Ord. 71-79, 9-8-1971)
   C.   Suits And Actions: The village attorney shall defend any and all suits
or actions at law or equity to which the village may be a party, or in which it
may be interested, or which may be brought against or by any officer of the
village, or in the capacity of such person as an officer of the village. (Ord.
71-79, 9-8-1971; amd. 2012 Code)
1-8B-4: COMPENSATION:
For such services, the village attorney shall be paid such salary and
compensation as shall be agreed upon by the village attorney and the board of
trustees at the time of appointment. (Ord. 71-79, 9-8-1971)
ARTICLE C. VILLAGE PROSECUTOR
SECTION:
1-8C-1: Office Created; Qualifications
1-8C-2: Appointment; Duties
1-8C-3: Assisted By Village Attorney
1-8C-4: Compensation
1-8C-1: OFFICE CREATED; QUALIFICATIONS:
There is hereby created the office of village prosecutor, who shall be an
attorney licensed to practice in the state. (Ord. 71-78, 9-8-1971)
1-8C-2: APPOINTMENT; DUTIES:
The village prosecutor shall be appointed by the village president and shall
prosecute all matters involving the violation of any ordinances of the village
or in which the village may be interested. (Ord. 71-78, 9-8-1971; amd. 2012
Code)
1-8C-3: ASSISTED BY VILLAGE ATTORNEY:
The village attorney shall assist the village prosecutor at the request of the
board of trustees. The village prosecutor shall notify the village attorney of
any notice of appeal served in connection with the imposition of any fine or
other penalty for a violation of a village ordinance. The village prosecutor
shall report to the village attorney on the progress of any matters which have
been continued from time to time and their final disposition. (Ord. 71-78, 9-8-
1971)
1-8C-4: COMPENSATION:
The compensation of the village prosecutor shall be as determined by the
village board of trustees. (Ord. 71-78, 9-8-1971; amd. 2012 Code)
ARTICLE D. VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR
SECTION:
1-8D-1: Title
1-8D-2: Office Created; Appointment And Term; Qualifications
1-8D-3: Oath Of Office
1-8D-4: Compensation
1-8D-5: Powers And Duties
1-8D-6: Conflict Of Interest
1-8D-7: Removal From Office
1-8D-8: Acting Village Administrator
1-8D-1: TITLE:
This article shall be entitled AN ORDINANCE CREATING AND ESTABLISHING THE
OFFICE OF VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR IN AND FOR THE VILLAGE OF BLOOMINGDALE. (Ord.
89-40, 9-25-1989)
1-8D-2: OFFICE CREATED; APPOINTMENT AND TERM; QUALIFICATIONS:
   A.   There is hereby created the office of village administrator. The
village administrator shall be appointed by the president, with the advice and
consent of the board of trustees, for such term as determined at the time of
his or her appointment or by contract or as otherwise provided by law. The
village administrator shall be chosen solely on the basis of his executive and
administrative qualifications, with special reference to his or her actual
experience in, and knowledge of, accepted practices in respect to the duties of
his or her employment as set forth herein. At the time of such appointment, the
village administrator need not be a resident of the village, but shall reside
either within the village or within reasonable distance therefrom during the
term of office.
   B.   Upon the appointment of the village administrator, the president shall
issue a certificate of appointment, under the corporate seal, to the village
clerk. The village administrator shall be commissioned by warrant, under the
corporate seal, signed by the village clerk and the president. (Ord. 89-40, 9-
25-1989)
1-8D-3: OATH OF OFFICE:
Before entering upon the duties of his office, the village administrator shall
take and subscribe the oath as set forth in 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/
3.1-10-25, as may be amended from time to time. This oath, so subscribed, shall
be filed in the office of the village clerk. (Ord. 89-40, 9-25-1989; amd. 2012
Code)
1-8D-4: COMPENSATION:
The village administrator shall receive such compensation and benefits as the
president and board of trustees shall determine by ordinance, or alternatively,
pursuant to any contract which defines said terms. No compensation shall be
paid to the village administrator in addition to that provided in the ordinance
or by the terms of any contract; except, however, the village administrator
shall be entitled to reimbursement for any reasonable actual expenses incurred
by him in the performance of his duties. (Ord. 89-40, 9-25-1989; amd. 2012
Code)
1-8D-5: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The village administrator shall be the administrative director of all
departments of the village. He shall be responsible to the president and board
of trustees for the proper administration of all affairs of the village. The
village administrator shall perform such duties in addition to those which may
be prescribed by law, and shall be subject to such other rules and regulations
as the president and board of trustees may provide by ordinance from time to
time. Specifically, but without limitation, the village administrator shall
have the following powers and duties: (Ord. 89-40, 9-25-1989; amd. 2012 Code)
   A.   Supervise and coordinate the work of all departments of the village now
in existence or that may hereafter be created by the president and board of
trustees, except as limited or restricted by any ordinance of the village;
(Ord. 89-40, 9-25-1989)
   B.   Recommend to the president and board of trustees in regard to the
hiring of all employees of the village. He shall recommend to the president the
removal or suspension of any department director or employee when such removal
or suspension shall be consistent with the village personnel manual and/or any
relevant provisions of the Illinois state statutes. All such recommendations
for the hiring of employees shall be based upon merit and qualifications. Any
recommendation for either hiring or removal shall be made without regard to
political belief or affiliation;
   C.   Review annually, salaries, wages and hours and conditions of employment
of all department directors and employees under his jurisdiction. No
expenditure shall be made on account of or pursuant to such appointment or
employment by the village administrator unless authorized by or under the
applicable appropriation or budget of the village, and all such expenditures
shall be subject to the approval of the president and board of trustees; (Ord.
89-40, 9-25-1989; amd. 2012 Code)
   D.   Act as purchasing agent of the village and make or supervise all
necessary purchases of equipment, materials and supplies by the village, and
all contracts therefor. The village administrator shall have the power to enter
into contracts for services and purchase goods and materials involving up to
and including thirty thousand dollars ($30,000.00) without the prior approval
of the village board, as long as those services, goods and materials have been
previously appropriated. Contracts and purchases in excess of this amount shall
require the prior approval of the village board, whether or not they have been
previously appropriated. The village administrator may issue rules and
regulations governing requisitions and the transaction of business of
purchasing between himself, as purchasing agent, and the department directors
and employees of the village; (Ord. 2011-35, 9-12-2011; amd. 2012 Code)
   E.   Make recommendations concerning compensation for each department
director and employed position in the service of the village, including
minimum, intermediate and maximum rates; (Ord. 89-40, 9-25-1989; amd. 2012
Code)
   F.   Recommend the creation, consolidation and combination of offices,
positions, departments or units of the administrative and executive departments
of the village;
   G.   Investigate all complaints in relation to matters concerning the
administration of the government of the village and services maintained by the
public utilities in the village, and see that all franchises, permits and
privileges granted by the village are faithfully observed; (Ord. 89-40, 9-25-
1989)
   H.   Prepare and present to the president for his consideration at the end
of each fiscal year an estimate of income and expenses for the ensuing year;
prepare the annual appropriation ordinance and tax levy ordinance in the form
and within the time required by law; and prepare the annual budget; and submit
such ordinances and budget to the president for his submittal to the board of
trustees, together with the village administrator's opinion and recommendations
covering their important features; and upon the adoption of such ordinances and
budget, the administration of the same. To the end that all financial matters
of the village are coordinated, the village finance director-treasurer is
hereby directed to cooperate with the village administrator and to assist him
in the performance of the duties imposed upon him by this article;
   I.   Act as business manager for the village under the direction of the
president and board of trustees and in cooperation with the village finance
director-treasurer and clerk; control and direct all expenditures made by the
village; supervise the keeping of all necessary records and books of accounts
of the village that are not under the supervision of the finance director-
treasurer or clerk, by ordinance or statute; (Ord. 89-40, 9-25-1989; amd. 2012
Code)
   J.   Attend all regular and special meetings of the village board, and
committees thereof, unless excused by the same;
   K.   Render or cause to be rendered monthly to the president and board of
trustees written statements showing the exact financial condition of the
village as of the end of the preceding month, including the statement of
current assets and liabilities, and a summarized statement of receipts and
expenditures;
   L.   Make recommendations to the president and board of trustees, or
appropriate committee thereof, relative to the adoption of such ordinances and
resolutions as he may deem necessary or expedient; meet with the standing
committees of the president and board of trustees as often as necessary and
when requested;
   M.   Make special reports or recommendations to the board of trustees, or
the appropriate committee thereof, as the board of trustees may request; (Ord.
89-40, 9-25-1989)
   N.   Render to all department directors of the village and said department
directors shall render to him all such assistance as is possible in the
performance of their respective duties, and all department directors and
employees of the village shall furnish and disclose to the village
administrator such oral or written information and material relating to the
affairs of the village as he shall request;
   O.   Keep a current inventory of all real and personal property of the
village and the location of such property; be responsible for the care and
custody of all village property which is not by law assigned to some other
department director or body for care and control; (Ord. 89-40, 9-25-1989; amd.
2012 Code)
   P.   Devote his entire time during reasonable hours to the discharge of his
official duties. He shall hold no other employment for compensation; except,
that he may receive occasional stipends for consultation with others not
connected with the village, making speeches, writing professional articles, and
the like; provided, that such secondary duties do not conflict with his duties
as village administrator; and
   Q.   Perform such other duties as may be required of him by the corporate
authorities not inconsistent with the statutes of the state of Illinois or with
the ordinances of the village. (Ord. 89-40, 9-25-1989; amd. Ord. 2024-47, 12-9-
2024)
1-8D-6: CONFLICT OF INTEREST:
The village administrator shall abide by the relevant provisions of the
Illinois Compiled Statutes pertaining to conflicts of interest, disclosures of
economic interests and contracts, including, but not limited to, 65 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/3.1-55-10 and 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 420/4A-101 et
seq., and as the same and any other relevant provisions of the state statutes
may be amended from time to time by the Illinois general assembly. The village
administrator shall promptly disclose any potential conflict of interest to the
president and board of trustees. (Ord. 89-40, 9-25-1989; amd. 2012 Code)
1-8D-7: REMOVAL FROM OFFICE:
The village administrator may be removed by the president on any formal charge
whenever the president is of the opinion that the interests of the village
demand removal. Such removal is subject to the payment of any valid remaining
portion of his contract, if hired by contract. The president shall report the
reasons for such removal to the village board at a meeting to be held not less
than five (5) nor more than ten (10) days after the removal. If the president
fails or refuses to report to the board of trustees the reasons for the
removal, or if the village board, by a two-thirds (2/3) vote of all its members
authorized by law to be elected, disapproves of the removal, the village
administrator, thereupon, shall be restored to office. Upon restoration, the
village administrator shall give a new bond and take a new oath of office.
(Ord. 89-40, 9-25-1989)
1-8D-8: ACTING VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR:
In the event the village administrator shall be incapacitated from performing
the duties of his position, a qualified person shall be appointed as acting
village administrator by the president, with the advice and consent of the
board of trustees, during such absence or incapacity, with all the powers and
duties of that office, who shall perform all the duties thereof without
furnishing any additional bond if such appointee shall already be under bond to
the village in any other capacity. If such appointment shall be a person not
already under bond to the village, such appointee shall furnish a bond in such
amount and with such surety as may be approved by the president and board of
trustees. The compensation to be paid the acting village administrator shall be
fixed by the president and board of trustees. (Ord. 89-40, 9-25-1989)
ARTICLE E. VILLAGE ENGINEER
SECTION:
1-8E-1: Appointment And Term; Residency
1-8E-2: Oath Of Office
1-8E-3: Compensation
1-8E-4: Duties And Responsibilities
1-8E-5: Conflict Of Interest
1-8E-6: Removal From Office
1-8E-1: APPOINTMENT AND TERM; RESIDENCY:
   A.   The Village Engineer shall be appointed by the President, with the
advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, for such term as determined at the
time of his appointment; however, such term of office shall expire no later
than the end of the term of the appointing President and as soon after as his
respective successor is appointed and has qualified. At the time of such
appointment, the Village Engineer need not be a resident of the Village, but
shall reside either within the Village or within a reasonable distance
therefrom during the term of office.
   B.   Upon the appointment of the Village Engineer, the President shall issue
a certificate of appointment, under the Corporate Seal, to the Village Clerk.
The Village Engineer shall be commissioned by warrant, under the Corporate
Seal, signed by the Village Clerk and the President. (Ord. 89-42, 9-25-1989;
amd. Ord. 2017-42, 11-13-2017)
1-8E-2: OATH OF OFFICE:
Before entering upon the duties of his office, the Village Engineer shall take
and subscribe the oath as set forth in 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3.1-10-
25, as may be amended from time to time. This oath, so subscribed, shall be
filed in the Office of the Village Clerk. (Ord. 89-42, 9-25-1989; amd. 2012
Code; Ord. 2017-42, 11-13-2017)
1-8E-3: COMPENSATION:
The Village Engineer shall receive such compensation as the President and Board
of Trustees shall determine by ordinance. No compensation shall be paid to the
Village Engineer in addition to that provided in the ordinance; except,
however, the Village Engineer shall be entitled to reimbursement for any
reasonable actual expenses incurred by him in the performance of his duties.
(Ord. 89-42, 9-25-1989; amd. 2012 Code; Ord. 2017-42, 11-13-2017)
1-8E-4: DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES:
   A.   The Village Engineer shall be generally responsible to the Corporate
Authorities in the performance of his statutory powers, duties and services,
but he shall be primarily responsible to and subject to the supervision,
direction and control of the Village Administrator. He shall be required to
attend regular and special meetings of the Village Board, Committee of the
Whole meetings and conferences as and when requested by the Village President,
the Board of Trustees and/or the Village Administrator.
   B.   The Village Engineer shall perform such duties, in addition to those
which may be prescribed by law, and shall be subject to such other rules and
regulations as the President and Board of Trustees may provide by ordinance
from time to time. Specifically, but without limitation, the Village Engineer
shall have the following duties: (Ord. 89-42, 9-25-1989; amd. Ord. 2017-42, 11-
13-2017)
      1.   Advise the Village President, Village Board of Trustees, and
Planning and Zoning Commission on all matters concerning the engineering and
construction of public works within the Village; (Ord. 89-42, 9-25-1989; amd.
2012 Code; Ord. 2014-48, 10-27-2014; Ord. 2017-42, 11-13-2017)
      2.   Review and approve or disapprove all engineering for all
subdivisions and public improvements within the corporate limits of the Village
and, to the extent permitted by State law or Village ordinance, for a distance
of one and one-half (11/2) miles outside the corporate limits of the Village;
      3.   Inspect and approve or disapprove the construction of all public
works within the corporate limits of the Village and, to the extent permitted
by State law or Village ordinance, for a distance of one and one-half (11/2)
miles outside the corporate limits of the Village;
      4.   Prepare all engineering plans and specifications for and the
supervision of all construction of all public improvements proposed to be
constructed by the Village; provided, that the President and Board of Trustees
may, in any instance where they deem it appropriate, retain an independent
engineer to prepare such engineering plans and specifications and supervise
such construction. In the event an independent engineer is retained as
aforesaid, the Village Engineer shall be responsible for the supervision of
such independent engineer and shall periodically report to the President and
Board of Trustees with respect to the performance of such independent engineer;
      5.   Prepare all long range planning and forecasts of public
improvements. The Village Engineer shall periodically advise the President,
Board of Trustees and the Village Administrator with respect thereto;
      6.   Maintain complete and accurate records of all public improvements in
the Village and establish standards for subdivision improvements as required by
the subdivision ordinance of the Village; and
      7.   Perform such other duties as may be delegated to him by the
ordinances of the Village or assigned to him by the President, the Board of
Trustees and/or the Village Administrator. (Ord. 89-42, 9-25-1989; amd. Ord.
2017-42, 11-13-2017)
1-8E-5: CONFLICT OF INTEREST:
The Village Engineer shall abide by the relevant provisions of the Illinois
Compiled Statutes pertaining to conflicts of interest, disclosure of economic
interests and contracts, including, but not limited to, 65 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/3.1-55-10 and 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 420/4A-101 et seq., and
as the same and any other relevant provisions of the State Statutes may be
amended from time to time by the Illinois General Assembly. The Village
Engineer shall promptly disclose any potential conflict of interest to the
Village Administrator. (Ord. 89-42, 9-25-1989; amd. 2012 Code; Ord. 2017-42,
11-13-2017)
1-8E-6: REMOVAL FROM OFFICE:
The Village Engineer may be removed by the President, on any formal charge,
whenever the President is of the opinion that the interests of the Village
demand removal. The President shall report the reasons for such removal to the
Village Board at a meeting to be held not less than five (5) nor more than ten
(10) days after the removal. If the President fails or refuses to report to the
Board of Trustees the reasons for the removal, or if the Village Board, by a
two-thirds (2/3) vote of all members authorized by law to be elected,
disapproves of the removal, the Village Engineer, thereupon, shall be restored
to office. Upon restoration, the Village Engineer shall give a new bond and
take a new oath of office. (Ord. 89-42, 9-25-1989; amd. Ord. 2017-42, 11-13-
2017)

CHAPTER 10
CODE OF ETHICS
SECTION:

1-10-1: STATEMENT OF POLICY AND INTENT:
   A.   All Village public officials and employees, paid or unpaid, hold their
positions for the benefit of the Village. They are bound to uphold the
Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the State of Illinois
and to carry out the laws of the Nation, the State and the Village. They are
obligated to faithfully discharge the duties of their office, acting
independently and impartially for the public interest. They are expected to
make and carry out decisions and policy within the proper channels of
government structure without prejudice or favoritism; the opportunity for
personal gain will not influence their actions or decisions. They are expected
to observe a high standard of conduct in the discharge of their official duties
and to avoid any actions that might, to a reasonable person, suggest the
appearance of impropriety.
   B.   This Code of Ethics, which defines the expectations of the community in
regard to the behavior of public officials and employees, is not intended to
work hardship on any individual dedicated to serving the public interest. It
should not exclude those who are best qualified to serve or work, nor violate
any individual's right to personal privacy. It is not intended to impair an
individual's ability to participate in functions associated with official
duties.
   C.   In recognition of these expectations, there is hereby established a
Code of Ethics for all public officials and employees. (Ord. 2004-59, 12-20-
2004)
1-10-2: DEFINITIONS:
APPOINTED OFFICERS: Shall include the Village Administrator, Finance Director-
Treasurer, Chief of Police and Village Engineer.
CAMPAIGN FOR ELECTIVE OFFICE: Any activity in furtherance of an effort to
influence the selection, nomination, election, or appointment of any individual
to any Federal, State or local public office or office in a political
organization, or the selection, nomination, or election of presidential or vice
presidential electors, but does not include activities:
   A.   Relating to the support or opposition of any executive, legislative, or
administrative action;
   B.   Relating to collective bargaining; or
   C.   That are otherwise in furtherance of the person's official duties.
CANDIDATE: A person who has filed nominating papers or petitions for nomination
or election to an elected office, or who has been appointed to fill a vacancy
in nomination, and who remains eligible for placement on the ballot at a
"regular election", as defined in section 1-3 of the Election Code 1 .
COLLECTIVE BARGAINING: Has the same meaning as that term is defined in section
3 of the Illinois Public Labor Relations Act 2 .
COMMISSIONER/COMMITTEE MEMBER: Individuals appointed by the Village President
who serve on the Planning and Zoning Commission, Board of Fire and Police
Commissioners, Septemberfest Commission, Family Fest Commission, Police Pension
Board, or any other Village commission or committee formed by ordinance or
resolution duly adopted by the Village Board of Trustees.
COMPENSATED TIME: Means, with respect to an employee, any time worked by or
credited to the employee that counts toward any minimum work time requirement
imposed as a condition of his or her employment, but for purposes of this
chapter, does not include any designated holidays, vacation periods, personal
time, compensatory time off or any period when the employee is on a leave of
absence. With respect to officers or employees whose hours are not fixed,
"compensated time" includes any period of time when the officer is on premises
under the control of the employer and any other time when the covered
individual is executing his or her official duties, regardless of location.
COMPENSATORY TIME OFF: Authorized time off earned by or awarded to an employee
to compensate, in whole or in part, for time worked in excess of the minimum
work time required of that employee as a condition of his or her employment.
CONTRIBUTION: Has the same meaning as that term is defined in section 9-1.4 of
the Election Code 3 .
COVERED INDIVIDUAL: Village President, Trustee, appointed officer, Village
employee, commission member, and committee member.
ELECTED OFFICIALS: Shall include the Village President, Village Clerk, and
Village Trustees.
EMPLOYEE: Any person employed by the Village, but does not include independent
contractors, subcontractors, or elected public officials, or members of
commissions or committees.
EMPLOYER: The Village of Bloomingdale.
GIFT: Any gratuity, discount, entertainment, hospitality, loan, forbearance, or
other tangible or intangible item having monetary value including, but not
limited to, cash, food and drink, and honoraria for speaking engagements
related to or attributable to government employment or the official position of
a covered individual.
LEAVE OF ABSENCE: Any period during which an employee does not receive:
   A.   Compensation for employment;
   B.   Service credit toward pension benefits; and
   C.   Health insurance benefits paid for by the employer.
OFFICER: A person who holds, by election or appointment, an office created by
statute or ordinance, regardless of whether the officer is compensated for
service in his or her official capacity, including, but not limited to, the
Village President, the Village Clerk, the Board of Trustees, the Village
Administrator, the Village Finance Director-Treasurer, the Chief of Police and
the Village Engineer.
POLITICAL ACTIVITY: Any activity in support of or in connection with any
campaign for elective office or any political organization, but does not
include activities:
   A.   Relating to the support or opposition of any executive, legislative, or
administrative action;
   B.   Relating to collective bargaining; or
   C.   That are otherwise in furtherance of the person's official duties.
POLITICAL ORGANIZATION: A party, committee, association, fund, or other
organization (whether or not incorporated) that is required to file a statement
of organization with the state board of elections or a county clerk under
section 9-3 of the election code 4 , but only with regard to those activities
that require filing with the state board of elections or county clerk.
PROHIBITED POLITICAL ACTIVITY: A. Preparing for, organizing, or participating
in any political meeting, political rally, political demonstration, or other
political event.
   B.   Soliciting contributions including, but not limited to, the purchase
of, selling, distributing, or receiving payment for tickets for any political
fundraiser, political meeting, or other political event.
   C.   Soliciting, planning the solicitation of, or preparing any document or
report regarding anything of value intended as a campaign contribution.
   D.   Planning, conducting, or participating in a public opinion poll in
connection with a campaign for elective office or on behalf of a political
organization for political purposes or for or against any referendum question.
   E.   Surveying or gathering information from potential or actual voters in
an election to determine probable vote outcome in connection with a campaign
for elective office or on behalf of a political organization for political
purposes or for or against any referendum question.
   F.   Assisting at the polls on election day on behalf of any political
organization or candidate for elective office or for or against any referendum
question.
   G.   Soliciting votes on behalf of a candidate for elective office or a
political organization or for or against any referendum question or helping in
an effort to get voters to the polls.
   H.   Initiating for circulation, preparing, circulating, reviewing, or
filing any petition on behalf of a candidate for elective office or for or
against any referendum question.
   I.   Making contributions on behalf of any candidate for elective office in
that capacity or in connection with a campaign for elective office.
   J.   Preparing or reviewing responses to candidate questionnaires in
connection with a campaign for elective office or on behalf of a political
organization for political purposes.
   K.   Distributing, preparing for distribution, or mailing campaign
literature, campaign signs, or other campaign material on behalf of any
candidate for elective office or for or against any referendum question.
   L.   Campaigning for any elective office or for or against any referendum
question.
   M.   Managing or working on a campaign for elective office or for or against
any referendum question.
   N.   Serving as a delegate, alternate, or proxy to a political party
convention.
   O.   Participating in any recount or challenge to the outcome of any
election.
PROHIBITED SOURCE: Any person or entity who:
   A.   Is seeking official action:
      1.   By an officer; or
      2.   By an employee, or by the officer or another employee directing that
employee;
   B.   Does business or seeks to do business:
      1.   With the officer; or
      2.   With an employee, or with the officer or another employee directing
that employee;
   C.   Conducts activities regulated:
      1.   By the officer; or
      2.   By an employee, or by the officer or another employee directing that
employee; or
   D.   Has interests that may be substantially affected by the performance or
nonperformance of the official duties of the covered individual. (Ord. 2004-59,
12-20-2004; amd. 2012 Code; Ord. 2014-48, 10-27-2014; Ord. 2017-42, 11-13-2017)
